thread.title: Which team would Yankees rather face in the Wild Card game?
thread.title_full: Which team would Yankees rather face in the Wild Card game?

author: Brendan Kuty | NJ Advance Media for NJ.com
title: Which team would Yankees rather face in the Wild Card game?
text:
NEW YORK — The Yankees were finally able to exhale when they grabbed a Wild Card spot Thursday night. 
But they still have reason to hold their breath. After all, the Yankees don't know two things. 
They aren't sure whether they'll have home-field advantage in the elimination game, though it's probable they will. Any combination of a Yankees victory or Astros loss over the next three days will clinch it. 
And they don't know their the Wild Card opponent. 
We've ranked the teams they would want to battle most below. 
1. Minnesota Twins (83-76) Record vs. Yankees in 2015: 1-5 
Why the Yankees want to face them: The Yankees have owned the Twins in four straight American League Division Series — 2003, 2004, 2009 and 2010. Plus, nobody on the Twins' pitching staff gives you chills. 
Why they don't: Miguel Sano had a pair of two homer games at Yankee Stadium in August. The rest of their offense, led by powerful second baseman Brian Dozier (28 homers), isn't too shabby either. 
2. Los Angeles Angels (83-76) 
Record vs. Yankees in 2015: 2-4 
Why the Yankees want to face them: Lefty Andrew Haney (6-3, 3.29 ERA) will start against the Yankees. Haney lacks experience, but he's been one of the best rookie pitchers in the game, and the Yankees hate facing lefties. 
Why they don't: Two names: Mike Trout and Albert Pujols, two of the game's most dangerous hitters. Also, top-notch closer Huston Street (groin) might be healthy enough to return. 
3. Houston Astros (84-75) 
Record vs. Yankees in 2015: 4-3 
Why the Yankees want to face them: The Astros are much worse on the road (31-47) than they are at home (52-28), and the Yankees are in good position to play host. Also, while Houston could throw at them lefty starting pitcher Dallas Keuchel, who's held the Yankees scoreless over 16 innings this year, he'd be going on short rest. 
Why they don't: Five Astros — Evan Gattis (27), Chris Carter (24), Luis Valbuena (24), Colby Rasmus (22) and Carlos Correa (21) — have hit 21 or more home runs and Masahiro Tanaka, the Yankees' Wild Card starting pitcher, is homer-prone, especially at in the Bronx.
